awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Axion Resonant InterAction DetectioN Experiment (ARIADNE)
awd_abstract_narration:
Multiple astronomical observations have established that about 85% of the matter in the universe is not made of known particles. Deciphering the nature of this so-called Dark Matter is of fundamental importance to cosmology, astrophysics, and high-energy particle physics. One of the most exciting quests in particle physics is the search for new particles beyond the Standard Model of particle physics. Extensions of the Standard Model predict not only new particles with large masses but also some with very small masses. Such a candidate is the axion, which has been introduced to explain the smallness of Charge-Parity (CP) violation in Quantum Chromodynamics and which turns out to also be a prime candidate for a constituent of the dark matter in the universe. This award will provide funds for R&D towards developing a new experiment to search for axion-like interactions between nuclei at sub-millimeter ranges. While participating in this research, a team of postdocs, graduate students and undergraduate researchers will be broadly trained in the various techniques of experimental atomic physics such as low-temperature physics, magnetic shielding, vacuum systems and modeling. 

The experiment involves a rotating non-magnetic mass to source the axion field, and a dense ensemble of laser-polarized He-3 nuclei to detect the axion field by NMR. The signal from an axion field can be resonantly enhanced by properly modulating the axion potential at the nuclear spin precession frequency. The method has the potential to improve previous experimental and astrophysical bounds on axions by several orders of magnitude and probe deep into the theoretically interesting regime for the Peccei-Quinn (PQ) axion. The experiment is also sensitive to more exotic axion-like particles. It is estimated that this method can ultimately exceed present laboratory constraints on spin-dependent short-range forces by up to eight orders of magnitude and can improve on the combined laboratory/astrophysical limits by a factor of 10^4 in the prime axion range of f_a between 10^9 and 10^12, probing deep into the theoretically interesting regime for the PQ axion. In contrast to cosmic axion searches, the setup is sensitive to the axion even if it does not make up most of the dark matter.

por.por_cntn:
This project conducted research and development on the ARIADNE experiment whose goal is to search for so-called "axion" particles, which are a theoretically well-motivated candidate for the dark matter of the universe. The nature of the dark matter of the universe, which seems to make up about 1/4 of the total energy budget of the universe, is a wide open scientific question, and so it is important to investigate all reasonable possibilities for its identity.  In this experiment we will look for a very small change in the direction of a collection of 3He nuclear spins by placing a notched tungsten mass nearby which would be the source of an axion field and spinning this mass at a rotation frequency which is in resonance with the 3He nuclear spins as they precess like tops in an external magnetic field. If the axion field exists the spinning mass will produce an oscillating axion field which interacts with the 3He spins and causes them to tip. We would detect this tip in direction using the same type of technology used in the magnetic resonance imaging employed in many hospitals.

Our responsibility was to develop the laser-based technique to polarize the 3He nuclear spins, to construct special gas handling systems to manipulate the rare and expensive 3He gas, to prepare a low temperature test system for the experiment (which must be conducted at 4 degrees above absolute zero), and to confirm that the residual magnetic fields of the tungsten mass  from possible impurities lodged in the metal are small enough not to cause a problem in the experiment. We succeeded in all of these R&D tasks. The R&D results of our collaborators at Northwestern, Stanford, and the Center for Axion and Precision Physics in Daejon, South Korea have also met the required technical specifications for the experiment which they were working on in parallel.

The broader impacts of this work consisted of the successful training of undergraduate and graduate students in science. Our PhD thesis students on the project have all gone on to secure postdoctoral research positions. Our undergraduate students have secured admission to physics PhD programs. Five of our undergraduate students won competitive international summer research positions at the Center for Axion and Precision Physics in South Korea which is one of our collaborating institutions and thereby enjoyed the rare opportunity to conduct research outside of the US as undergraduates. The Indiana University Office of Engagement made a video of one of our undergraduate students to use as encouragement for other IU undergraduates to pursue undergraduate research projects.
